oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cleburne Jersey Farm: farmhouse front view with dairy house and cattle barn
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 2319 Sugar Ridge Rd, Spring Hill, TN

Color photograph of the south facade of the two-story white wood-framed house with Italianate architectural details. Features include a broad porch across the front of the house with nine arches, wrought-iron balustrade above the porch, arched windows, wide eave overhangs with carved brackets, peaked gable roof and latticework at ground level. The dairy house and cattle barn are visible to the west and rear of the house.

The Cleburne Jersey Farm dates to approximately 1872, when the extant Italianate-styled home and limestone dairy house were built for the Campbell family. Prior to the Civil War the farm was part of a large plantation belonging to George Washington Campbell. Following the war, the land was divided into the Ewell farm and the Cleburne farm, where McCoy (Mack) Campbell soon built the first herd of Jersey dairy cattle in Tennessee. In the 1880s, the property began to be called the Cleburne Jersey Farm, and in 1885 the dairy herd was significantly expanded. The Campbell family played a large role in establishing the Jersey as a leading breed of dairy cattle both through breeding and by importing stock from the Isle of Jersey. At the time of it's nomination to the National Register of Historic Places the farm was still held and managed by members of the Campbell family.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Historic farms -- Tennessee
Farmhouses; Barns
